description.text: This image, a calendar for the year 1935 (December), has a woman wearing a sari and sitting at a table. The table has a high shine and her reflection is visible on it. She is seated on an Empire style chair upholstered in green velvet. The contact details of the advertised company as well as the individual calendar leaf for the month of December is also visible. On the left side is another small ad, in blue, with a sari-clad woman looking at a soap bar of 'Royal Khus'. The slogan reads 'Secret of Beauty'. To the right of the calendar leaf is an ad for Margosam Neem Soap. Medicated Luxury Toilet "Better than the Best", showing the head of a woman and a soap bar.

inscription.text: Telephone: HWH. 650 Telegrama: "KAMSOFAC" MAHALUXMI SOAP WORKS 59, COTTON STREET, CALCUTTA SOLE AGENT FOR U. P. Babu Radha Krishna Tandon, Phulwali-Gulli, Lucknow
Secret of Beauty ROYAL KHUS MAHALUXMI SOAP WORKS CALCUTTA

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: December 1935 Advertisement calendar for Mahaluxmi Soap Works

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: This image, a calendar for the year 1935 (December), has a woman wearing a sari and sitting at a table. The table has a high shine and her reflection is visible on it. She is seated on an Empire style chair upholstered in green velvet. The contact details of the advertised company as well as the individual calendar leaf for the month of December is also visible. On the left side is another small ad, in blue, with a sari-clad woman looking at a soap bar of 'Royal Khus'. The slogan reads 'Secret of Beauty'. To the right of the calendar leaf is an ad for Margosam Neem Soap. Medicated Luxury Toilet "Better than the Best", showing the head of a woman and a soap bar.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This 1935 calendar from Mahaluxmi Soap Works depicts an upper class modern Indian woman. Clearly influenced by conventions of studio portraiture, the artist paints the woman posing self reflexively. Invisible in this image, the advert speaks about the symbolic value of soap in transforming her appearance that is highlighted through a "double" image. The use of mirrors and reflective surfaces in soap advertising has been noted by McClintock: “Mirrors glint and gleam in soap advertising…The mirror became the epitome of commodity fetishism: erasing both the signs of domestic labor and the industrial origins of domestic commodities. In the domestic world of mirrors, objects multiply without apparent human intervention in a promiscuous economy of self- generation.” If the woman in the advertisement is indeed a housewife, then this image erases all signs of work focusing instead on the associations of soap with modernity: with being fashionable (note her hair and stylish broach), living in a clean home and having time for leisure. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Even in a calendar for the Mahaluxmi Soap Company of Calcutta from 1955 advertising soaps to be used in the home, the image focuses on the results of cleaning, not the process. Here a carefully made up woman with flowers in her hair gazes at us invitingly over an immaculately shined table—a table that reflects her image so perfectly that it must have just been cleaned, even if no cleaning implements are visible, and even if the woman depicted looks to be more of a seductress than a housekeeper. Work is implied in these images: someone has to keep the house clean, prepare snacks, and arrange the flowers. But that work is invisible—fulfilling the need, as Anne McClintock argues, to represent middle-class domesticity without depicting women engaged in the labor which was now increasingly associated with the lower classes. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: All three women (including the small ads at the bottom of the poster) have the air of 'whiteness' and the elegant habitus of a cosmopolitan that shows in their hairstyle and facial expression. However, they also underline a 'conservative' Indianness of a 'homemaker' by wearing classical golden jewellery and sari.() (cb)

This 1935 calendar from Mahaluxmi Soap Works depicts an upper class modern Indian woman. Clearly influenced by conventions of studio portraiture, the artist paints the woman posing self reflexively. Invisible in this image, the advert speaks about the symbolic value of soap in transforming her appearance that is highlighted through a "double" image. The use of mirrors and reflective surfaces in soap advertising has been noted by McClintock: “Mirrors glint and gleam in soap advertising…The mirror became the epitome of commodity fetishism: erasing both the signs of domestic labor and the industrial origins of domestic commodities. In the domestic world of mirrors, objects multiply without apparent human intervention in a promiscuous economy of self- generation.” If the woman in the advertisement is indeed a housewife, then this image erases all signs of work focusing instead on the associations of soap with modernity: with being fashionable (note her hair and stylish broach), living in a clean home and having time for leisure.

All three women (including the small ads at the bottom of the poster) have the air of 'whiteness' and the elegant habitus of a cosmopolitan that shows in their hairstyle and facial expression. However, they also underline a 'conservative' Indianness of a 'homemaker' by wearing classical golden jewellery and sari.

Even in a calendar for the Mahaluxmi Soap Company of Calcutta from 1955 advertising soaps to be used in the home, the image focuses on the results of cleaning, not the process. Here a carefully made up woman with flowers in her hair gazes at us invitingly over an immaculately shined table—a table that reflects her image so perfectly that it must have just been cleaned, even if no cleaning implements are visible, and even if the woman depicted looks to be more of a seductress than a housekeeper. Work is implied in these images: someone has to keep the house clean, prepare snacks, and arrange the flowers. But that work is invisible—fulfilling the need, as Anne McClintock argues, to represent middle-class domesticity without depicting women engaged in the labor which was now increasingly associated with the lower classes.
